Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 3-4 hours for readings. 1-2 on grant proposal weeks.
4 hours
2-5 hours per week
2-3 for reading assignments and reflection
Approx. 4 hours per week, up to 8-10 hours when a larger assignment was due.
5 hours/week

6hrs for weekly readings + reflection
Beginning in February, an additional 3-4hrs weekly for the final project.
20 hours
3hours
6 hrs/ week outside classroom
5-10 hours

It should cover more BROADLY what global health is, and not just the typical infectious diseases etc. (there could be less on this and more on NCDs etc.). Also really didn't like the final report because people who had already done a Down's (or other) fellowship application were at an advantage and either already had a report finished/had skills on HOW to write it. A lot of this course (Even the reflections) were very vague and I never knew what I was being asked to do until I got feedback (and didn't do so well marks-wise).
Excellent course, well structured and interesting content

I think this class was extremely interesting. I enjoyed hearing from all of the guest speakers and other students in the class about various global efforts, issues, and experiences. I do think, however, that if you're going to "require" attendance in class on Friday mornings, you should probably take attendance or something, because a lot of people just didn't show up. Also, maybe not hold the class once a week on a Friday morning.

I like the idea of students presenting on the weekly readings.
The instructions for the reading responses were unclear, and I had already submitted 3 assignments before one had been graded, so I received points off for all three assignments. 
Assignments were not discussed in class, so it was difficult to know what the professor was expecting.
The course should be titled "Critical Issues in Global Health Research." We essentially only talked about research, and not about global health practice. 
I wish there was at least one person (besides the dean) on the panel for the last class who was not in EMD. Not everyone in that class is an EMD student and we could have gained a lot from having someone with a different perspective, background, and focus.

The weekly readings were interesting and they covered a range of significant global health issues, but the readings were dense and the write-ups required too much. If it was just a reading response it would be fine but having to constantly think about challenges, threats to your opinions etc, ruined the readings for me. Additionally, I didn't like that the write-ups were due Tuesday when classes were held on Friday...we basically got 3 days to work on them which was another obstacle for me considering how long/heavy the readings were. I also wish this course was not on a Friday, that definitely caused a strain on students who go away for the weekend/ go to work that day.

I liked this course. I thought the the structure of the course (with guest lecturers, drafting a proposal, etc.) was pragmatic and organized. It felt more like a seminar series. Additionally, his TFs were highly organized and responsive to student inquiries. The course did have a somewhat disjunct feel the lectures, while all related to GH, were disjointed in their specific topic area. This is not a fault of the course, but is representative of the scope of the class: in the course of the semester, it tried to introduce students to critical issues in the field of GH (an impossible task) but I feel like it succeeded in addressing the major issues. I also really liked the panelists at the end of the class which, from what I understand, were student organized. I would like to see more of this. Lastly, I felt that the grade expectations of this class were somewhat cryptic, and this could be improved. Kaveh/TFs did not really discuss deadlines in class, so if you weren't paying attention to the syllabus, you were liable to miss something. Otherwise, great class.
Some of the speakers that came were very engaging. I would have preferred for more lectures in the course.
Excellent, very interactive

This course could have used a bit more discussion. The most engaging sessions were the ones where we got to break into smaller groups, but that was rare. There were a wealth of experiences and insights into material that students had, but it was harder to share. Perhaps if the student led lectures were discussion/activity based rather than summarizing the material that we read it would have allowed for more engagement. There were multiple presentations that had discussion questions, but often we did not have enough time to engage with this.
Great course!

Course is good, though the last session (the panel) would've been good to have at the very beginning so that students can learn about the different paths they can take in global health. Class is more of a seminar, but would've like less student presentations (many of them took too long)
Good overall, but I think it should have been a lot more engaging
I really enjoyed the course, and particularly enjoyed the diversity of topics covered, the relevance to current events, and the guest speakers who were invited.

This course was very disappointing at times. Overall, the fact that I was basically just taught by my fellow students was the biggest let down. Every class was just students summarizing the readings I already did. What was the point of that? That was a waste of time. Then the guest speaker would talk about their work which was interesting but this course felt no different than the fall seminar. I've been very disappointed by the required global health courses so far and am unhappy I chose to stick with the concentration. I've just been wasting my time in these courses. Also, the massive grant project was rarely if ever discussed in class and that's ridiculous. The TFs would send out random reminders days before assignments were due and never discuss them in class. That's unacceptable. Also they would take forever to grade assignments. I had a reading response from February graded in May, like really? It seemed like none of the instructors took this course seriously and I was forced to waste my time and money.
I learned a lot from my fellow classmates presentation. However, I don't think that the reading reflections were helpful for my overall learning.

This was an excellent course. The format of small group presentations and a overall research proposal was very conducive to learn about global health. I wish the class size was a little smaller, but otherwise it was fantastic!

Strengths: 
- touches on a variety of significant themes in global health
- deliverable at the end (i.e. individual project)
Weaknesses: 
- highly un-engaging lecture format for a majority of the guest lectures; perhaps greater small group discussions would have fostered participation
- perhaps a 5min break in the middle of the 2hour class would be helpful for engagement, especially since students are just "talked at" for 2 hours
- while a variety of concepts were touched upon, the final project was essentially individual work with minimal support; it devolved into a copy/paste of a lot of Downs Proposals by students who had created such proposals the prior semester, leaving other students like myself floundering to individually concoct a project with little guidance
- quite delayed feedback on reflections (receiving a grade for the first one after 3-4 had already been written)
- would have LOVED to hear more of Prof Khoshnood's actual work throughout the course, as he mainly functioned as a facilitator inviting guest lecturers and having students conduct presentations

Strength: Excellent conversations and guest speakers.

Weaknesses: Would have it scheduled on any day apart from Friday. Making it to class was sometimes difficult with other priorities.

The course was well thought out and the TAs provided excellent feedback. The readings were very relevant to global health issues that we have encountered or may encounter in our research. The week's readings covered a diverse array of topics in global health. It would helpful to have some more background/overview of the topic at the start of the class before the student presentations. We not only discussed how to apply the lessons learned to our research, but the skills needed to work through the problems that may arise.

The overall course was great. It challenged me to think critically about global health and its issues. I learned a lot about health system strengthening, capacity building, specific infectious diseases, and the debate about global health. I believe I am more apt to be a global health practitioner after taking this course, as I have improved my skills to think critically about ethics and reasons for doing research. As well, it gave me tools to think about who is benefiting from studies and the role of larger institutions in promoting inequity. I liked the readings and associated reflections. I think they were useful to synthesize the readings and allowing students to share their own lens. It permitted more thoughtful conversation because students were forced to think about their beliefs. However, I think it would be more beneficial to make the assignments due on Wednesday night or Thursday night as opposed to Tuesday for a Friday class. Each day during the week counts in making it more manageable. With respect to the project proposal, I loved working through it and it made me able to write an effective grant. However, I think there should be a little bit more of a guidance on what to include in each sub-section (even if it is just section breakdowns with a sentence on what to include).
Would have liked more feedback from the professor, rather than just the TFs on assignments.

I enjoyed this course. I would however suggest not having the reflection due date so much earlier than the class. As well as, I would encourage there be a better explanation of the reflections, because they were graded harder than expected. I think there just needed be clearer expectations about the assignments and the level of detail wanted from the beginning, because it was only later I would understand how much detail was needed.

The strength of this course is the diversity of subjects and that theres a new speaker every week.

However, I feel like this course does not critique global health as much as it could. I feel like it needs to take an even more strict anti-colonialism stance
Really wonderful space for students to have thoughtful discussions about aspects of global health, as well as critical reflection on Yale's role in the field.

Strength: Varied topics and guest speakers

Weaknesses: Tuesday deadlines were early for Friday discussion

Class was good, However it would have been beneficial to talk about the research proposal at least ONCE during lectures. And work on timing of assignments and readings... a lot of this course felt rushed and disorganized.
it is a great course

A good course to gain an idea of the current issues in global health. However, it felt as though the larger graded assignment for the class, a research proposal focused on a global health issue, was unrelated to the overall class. This assignment and its associated parts were never actually discussed in class.
very good
Very kind and made me comfortable enough to contribute. Would like it if he worked more with the TFs because it seemed like they had different perceptions of expectations for each assignment.
Wonderful professor

Kaveh is a brilliant man. He knows a lot and has a lot of experience in different areas. He was respectful and open to students' comments and ideas. I really liked how he took time each week to personally meet with the group that was presenting. I wish he had lectured more, and facilitated more discussions as opposed to sooo many guest speakers though.
The instructor did a great job at raising some very important issues in the class.
Professor Khoshnood is kind, soft spoken, and helpful. I enjoyed discussing my research proposal and group presentation with him. He is easy to talk to and passionate about helping his students.
Very caring, professional instructor. I appreciated his availability to meet with groups that were presenting readings in front of the class.
Good teacher. Really knowledgable about the topics.
He's very responsive to questions and always encouraging
Did a great job!
Professor Khoshnood is very passionate and teaches this course well and brings in a lot of interesting discussion.
Professor Khoshnood is one of my favorite professors! He is so supportive of students and presents interesting topics in a brand new perspective.
Nice professor, very open to talking to students
Kaveh is great

The professor was very encouraging of participation. The only critique I have is that I would have liked to hear slightly more from him on the subject matter rather than always being taught by other classmates and visiting speakers.

Dr. Khoshnood was an amazing instructor, always willing to meet and discuss topics during and outside of class time. He was very supportive throughout the semester and genuinely cared for every student.
Very compassionate and supportive teacher. I would boldly state he is the top 3 best YSPH faculty we have.

Professor Khoshnood covered each topic in a great amount of detail and the class discussions were incredibly engaging. I especially appreciated how we covered the ethical dilemmas involved in each of the topics. He provided excellent feedback on the assignments and in the process of building our research proposals.
He is a great lecturer! I learned a lot from this class.

Kaveh is a fantastic professor that inspires his students. His own experiences with global health and domestic health have inspired the students. He is able to bring multiple lenses to the issue, as a researcher and individual. By listening to his mentees' work, his own work, and his lived experience, I feel more knowledgeable about global health and what it entails. As well, he inspires the class to think critically about issues and express their concerns and thoughts. It makes for good class discussion. He brought in many speakers that had a wide span over the public health field.
More classes taught by the professor and fewer guest speakers needed to truly evaluate his teaching, but he was very effective in the way he taught.

Kaveh is such and interesting and knowledgeable instructor and I would love if the class engaged more with him and not necessarily as much with the outside guests. I think he has a lot of experience and teachable material we could learn from, and I would have loved to hear from him more than just the one day we had him on a panel.
Thoughtful and deeply knowledgeable. Able to guide discussion organically. Really enjoyed his teaching.
he is knowledgeable and great professor
Great instructor who clearly has a wealth of expertise and knowledge in global health issues. Very clearly took the time to select relevant weekly guest speakers.
Excellent job
Maybe if there was more variety of GH content.
Highly recommend for students with interest in global health topics

I would. I think when going into the global health field, it is really important to hear what's going on and get new ideas from different people and places. I also think hearing about others' experiences or opinions on things broadens the way you look at topics. It was very inclusive and interesting. I enjoyed it a lot.

Take this course if you are okay with a heavy workload. The readings are long and there is a write-up due every week. Additionally, the roll-out of the research paper occurs in three stages which can be burdensome. You also have to be a person who enjoys a Friday morning class!

Broad introduction to critical issues in global health. Panel discussions with faculty, student led presentations, poster session, grant proposal drafting process. Highly pragmatic course, and necessary for those students who are enrolled in the global health concentration.
I would have preferred the course to be more lectured based rather than having students summarizing the readings. There was also drastic variation in the grading between the two TFs.
It was overall an okay course. It is a requirement of the global health concentration, but it wasn't the best course I've had at YSPH.
This is one of the best courses I have taken so far.  I highly recommend this class to any and all students!
Essentially a seminar. A lot of overlap with the global health seminar in the fall and this class.
It is an enjoyable course, provides exposure to a variety of topics. I would recommend it.
This class is an absolute must for any student with a global health focus, or interested in learning more about global health!

Interesting in topics that are raised and quite a few relevant readings. 
Guest speakers come from a variety of global health experiences but lacked conversation regarding HARD skills and TOOLS to develop to create a sustainable global health career.
However, the weekly 2-hour sessions without a break is quite challenging. Also, lack of transparency of attendance leaves classes 2/3-full (at best).
For people who want to discuss complex global health ideas. Good range of expertise in the room as well.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student.
yes I would definitely recommend.

This course is worth taking. It will enable you to think critically about global health, ethics, and various diseases/topics. Kaveh is a fantastic professor that inspires his students to learn, think, and express. The workload is manageable.

Its a good course, you really learn a lot of different global health topics, so that caveat is you may not be interested in a lot of it. It is a lot of reading and you have to stay on top of it, but at the end on presentation day you really learn how cool and interesting all of the work classmates want to do are!
Engaging course where you develop your writing skills and have the opportunity to explore global health through a critical lens.

it is definitely a great course. i have learnt a lot from this course. however, the class requires a lot of research knowledge and skills and public health knowledge. it gives you a lot of tedious work. as someone who dislikes research and has no experience in public health or global health, i was struggling. take it when your schedule is light or if you love public health or research.
Would recommend as a course by which to survey global health issues.
Great learning experience
